Aristotle: Animals, Emotion and Moral Virtue
Fortenbaugh examines apparent contradictions in Aristotle’s pronouncements on intellectual and moral qualities in animals between his ethical treatises and his biological treatises
Ancient Natural History: Histories of Nature
De la Phronesis Animale
Biologie, Logique et Métaphysique chez Aristote (Paris: Éditions du Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique
The author analyzes the meanings and degrees of intellect in animals that Aristotle’s use of the term phronesis entails
The Essence of Aristotle’s Zoology
Pratt argues that Aristotle’s main interest in biology was not in classifying animals but in understanding why they have the characteristics that they possess by nature
Animal and Human Souls in the Peripatetic School
Science and Philosophy in Aristotle’s Biological Works
The work contains useful information on Aristotle’s role as an observational biologist

Some Stock Illustrations of Animal Intelligence

title: The Greek Anthropocentric View of Man
Das Verhältnis
Animals, Gods and Humans: Changing Attitudes to Animals in Greek, Roman and Early Christian Ideas
Gilhus offers a detailed discussion of the place of plants and animals in the Manichean scheme of the universe
Biopsicologia e Giustizia verso gli Animali in Teofrasto e Plutarco
This study maintains that Plutarch employed material from Theophrastus to argue that one can be both just and pious toward animals
Theophrastus and Zeno on Moral Theory
123–145. Brink considers the Theophrastean contribution to oikeiosis theory to be exaggerated and the importance of the idea to Stoic ethics to be overstated by scholars
Die Oikeiosis-Lehre Theophrasts
This is the most influential argument for Theophrastean influence on the development of subsequent oikeiosis theory

container-title: Theophrastean Studies on Natural Science, Physics and Metaphysics, Ethics, Religion, and Rhetoric
Obbink speculates on the structure of Theophrastus’ lost treatise On Piety, and declares it valuable as a Peripatetic vision of the doctrine of oikeiosis
title: The Origin of Greek Sacrifice: Theophrastus on Religion and Cultural History
Oikeiosis
This chapter offers valuable discussion of the etymology of the term oikeiosis
The Role of Oikeiosis in Stoic Ethics
Striker discusses the connection of the concept of oikeiosis with Stoic notions of the origins of justice
The Epicurean Analysis of Language
DeLacy argues that the Epicureans took a practical view of language as a tool arising from convention and necessity, and that they scorned poetic and metaphorical language as unscientific and useless
Morals by Agreement
This volume sets forth a modern ethical system based on contract theory
The Epicureans, Animals, and Freewill
Huby demonstrates that the Epicureans seem to have accorded freewill to humans but not to animals
Epicurus’ Ethical Theory: The Pleasures of Invulnerability
Mitsis offers an extended discussion of the part played by contract forming in Epicurean ethics, although without specific reference to animals

Suggestions for Further Reading 1
Hunting in the Ancient World

This standard work discusses hunting from Homer through the late Roman Empire, concentrating on sport hunting. Organized by historical periods, the work contains a useful index of passages in ancient literature that discuss hunting
The Hunt in Ancient Greece
Barringer analyzes what the hunt meant in archaic and classical Greece, and makes much use of evidence from Greek pottery
A View to a Death in the Morning: Hunting and Nature through History
This fascinating work, thematically organized, discusses man’s urge to kill and his shame at killing animals throughout history

note: Hughes discusses hunting in ancient societies from prehistoric times through the classical period, with useful comments on the detrimental effects that hunting had on animal populations in Greece and Rome.
title: Hunting in the Ancient Mediterranean World
A Cultural History of Animals in Antiquity
Ecology in Ancient Civilizations
Hughes discusses the devastating influence that the Roman appetite for arena sports had on the animal populations of Africa and Asia
Beastly Spectacles in the Ancient Mediterranean World

A Cultural History of Animals in Antiquity 97–126. Shelton discusses animals in both sacrificial and entertainment contexts from the Greek Bronze Age through Roman imperial times, with emphasis on Roman arena sports
